awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Elucidating the Drivers and Consequences of Changes in Atmospheric Rivers from the Last Glacial Maximum to the Present Day
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to investigate the response of atmospheric rivers (ARs) to changes in the mean climate state and radiative forcing. This will be accomplished using a new set of paleoclimate simulations from the Community Earth System Model (CESM2) with the goal to understand the processes that drive past, present and future ARs responses, and evaluate their impact on regional hydroclimates and ecosystems. The researchers plan to conduct eight different experiments with the CESM2 in which ice sheets, orbital configurations, meltwater fluxes and carbon dioxide concentrations will be varied independently since the last glacial maximum. An ARs tracking algorithm will be implemented to objectively identify ARs across climate states and then used to quantify the distribution, frequency, intensity, and seasonal character of ARs changes and their impact on precipitation. The project is organized about three specific objectives: 1) develop a robust AR tracking algorithm for use in climate change studies; 2) understand the relationships between ARs and climate system forcings; and 3) quantify the contribution of AR changes to regional hydroclimate over the last glacial-interglacial transition. 

The potential Broader Impacts include a better understanding of the role of ARs within the climate system. An international collaboration is planned to conduct an official Atmospheric River Tracking Method Intercomparison activity with the resulting AR catalogues being archived and made publicly available. 

The project supports the training of a graduate student and a Postdoctoral scholar. In addition, a professional development workshop for regional high school teachers will be organized as part of an ongoing program at the University of Massachusetts Lowell. A set of modules centered on the physics of the climate system and the interdisciplinary applications of climate science will be developed and made available to the workshop participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on understanding the response of atmospheric rivers to climate forcing factors since the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) (about 21,000 years ago) and estimating the impact of these atmospheric river responses on past hydroclimate.

The first outcome of the project was the development of an automated atmospheric river detection algorithm suitable for application across different climate states. Because the climate state strongly influences what constitutes an atmospheric river, the algorithm incorporates climate-dependent and seasonally-dependent features of the climate state to establish appropriate criteria for atmospheric river detection regardless of the background climate. The algorithm was then validated for the modern climate, showing good agreement with prior estimates of modern-day atmospheric river activity, and applied to our newly created climate model simulations to study the behavior of atmospheric rivers in Earth?s past.  The algorithm has since been included as part of several atmospheric river tracking method intercomparison projects to quantify the role that structural differences in algorithms have on our understanding of atmospheric rivers.

The second outcome of the project was the creation of a set of ten climate model simulations with the Community Earth System Model (CESM) designed to investigate atmospheric river responses to key climate forcing factors since the LGM. The climate forcing factors explored in the project include carbon dioxide concentration, ice sheet albedo, ice sheet height, meltwater fluxes, and insolation seasonality. 100 years of model data was created and archived for each simulation, including a subset of data at a 6-hourly temporal resolution, providing novel insights into high-impact weather phenomena in past climates. 

Results indicate that atmospheric river characteristics, including frequency, location, and precipitation rate/type are highly sensitive to climate system forcings, and as such, have had a major role in shaping hydroclimate change since the LGM. We have quantified how each climate forcing shapes atmospheric river behavior and identified the underlying mechanisms. We find that changes to the location and intensity of landfalling ARs in response to seasonal insolation changes explain most of the precipitation change since the mid-Holocene in several midlatitude regions, including the west coast of North America, coastal East Asia, and Chile. The results provide a plausible physical atmospheric mechanism for previously hypothesized changes to moisture sources and precipitation intensity across these regions inferred from proxy records. We also find that atmospheric river activity during glacial climates like the LGM varies considerably from the modern, driven primarily by the presence of ice sheets. Regionally, atmospheric river activity and associated extreme precipitation was substantially increased in the North Atlantic during the LGM, despite overall cooler and drier conditions across the globe. This increase was driven primarily by enhanced temperature gradients (baroclinicity) in the region from greater ice coverage, highlighting the physical mechanisms behind changing atmospheric river intensity.

Outside of the mid-latitudes, we focused our analysis on the role of atmospheric rivers in shaping ice sheet mass balance. We find that atmospheric rivers were likely a major contributor to the surface mass balance of ice sheet margins at the LGM. At that time, the equatorward margins of the expansive continental ice sheets intersected the poleward edges of the atmospheric river storm tracks. Despite the cold temperatures during the LGM, most atmospheric rivers brought warm temperatures and liquid precipitation to the ice sheet margins, creating conditions for ice sheet melt. This suggests that atmospheric rivers may have had a role in driving the movement of ice sheets during Earth's past. Pending publications examine the role of North Atlantic meltwater fluxes on local and remote atmospheric river activity, and the changing role of atmospheric rivers in driving global heat transport.

Regarding Broader Impacts, the PIs organized and facilitated an Atmospheric River Tracking Method Intercomparison Project (ARTMIP) Tier-2 activity to extend the scope of the paleoclimate atmospheric river analysis to include atmospheric river detection algorithms from across the atmospheric river community. Data from four of the CESM paleoclimate simulations was shared with 12 participating ARTMIP members to examine the robustness of the atmospheric river responses, and our associated understanding of past climate changes, to the choice of detection algorithm. The project also funded three professional development workshops for K-12 teachers focused on incorporating climate science in the classroom. The workshops were held at the University of Massachusetts Lowell and were attended by over 50 teachers from across New England. As part of the workshop, the PIs developed modules using ?diynamics? kits to demonstrate geophysical fluid principles. Lastly, the project also funded the training and professional development of one graduate student at UMass Lowell, and two postdoctoral scholars and a postgraduate student at Yale University.
